tit.e: To (a unit of volume in old Japanese system of weight and measures)
To (a unit of volume in old Japanese system of weight and measures)

sen.e: "To" (Volume unit)
To (斗; a unit of volume)
sen.cmt: 英語の「to」との混同を避けるため、漢字を補足しました。
sen.e: To (斗; a unit of volume)

sen.j: 尺貫法における体積（容積）の単位。
sen.e: "To" is an unit of volume in the East Asian system of weights and measures.
sen.cmt: （注）「尺貫法」は、狭義では日本独特の度量衡の単位系を、広義では東アジア共通の度量衡の単位系を指します。ここでは「斗」が日本・中国双方の単位であるところからみて広義に用いられていると解されます。
sen.e: To is a unit of volume in the East Asian system of weights and measures.
To is a unit of volume in the East Asian system of weights and measures.
"To" is the name of the eleventh string of "so" (a long Japanese zither with thirteen strings).
To is the name of the 11th string of so (a long Japanese zither with 13 strings).
To is the name of the 11th string of so (a long Japanese zither with 13 strings).

sen.j: 本項では1.について述べる。
sen.e: In this section, the first "to" is explained.
In this section, the former is explained.
In this section, the former is explained.
10 "sho" is equalized with 1 "to," and 10 "to" is equalized with 1 "stone" (sho and stone are also the units of volume).
10 sho is equalized with 1 to, and 10 to is equalized with 1 koku (sho and koku are also the units of volume).
10 sho is equalized with 1 to, and 10 to is equalized with 1 koku (sho and koku are also the units of volume).

sen.j: 日本では、明治時代に1升＝1.8039リットルと定められたので、1斗＝18.039リットルとなる。
sen.e: In Japan, 1 sho was set at 1.8039 liter in the Meiji period, so 1 "to" became 18.039 liters.
In Japan, 1 sho was set at 1.8039 liters in the Meiji period, so 1 to became 18.039 liters.
In Japan, 1 sho was set at 1.8039 liters in the Meiji period, so 1 to became 18.039 liters.

sen.j: 中国では、1升＝1リットルと定められたので、1斗＝10リットルとなる。
sen.e: In China, 1 sho was set at 1 litter, so 1 "to" ('dou' in pinyin) became 10 liters.
In China, 1 sho was set at 1 liter, so 1 to (dou in pinyin) became 10 liters.
In China, 1 sho was set at 1 liter, so 1 to (dou in pinyin) became 10 liters.

sen.j: ただし、時代によって異なり、時代が下るに連れ容積が大きくなる傾向にある。
sen.e: However, the volume of "to" differs from time to time, and it tends to become larger as the time comes closer to today.
However, the volume of to differs from time to time, and it tends to become larger as the time comes closer to today.
However, the volume of to differs from time to time, and it tends to become larger as the time comes closer to today.

sen.j: 周代は1.94リットルであったが、秦代に3.43リットル。
sen.e: In the age of the Zhou dynasty, 1 "to" was set at 1.94 liter, and in the age of the Qin dynasty, 1 "to" was set at 3.43 liters.
1 to was set at 1.94 liters in the age of the Zhou Dynasty, and it was at 3.43 liters in the Qin Dynasty.
1 to was set at 1.94 liters in the age of the Zhou Dynasty, and it was at 3.43 liters in the Qin Dynasty.

sen.j: 後漢で1.98リットルに一度減るが、その後は魏 (三国)・西晋で2.02リットル、隋・唐で5.94リットルなどと増え続け、明代には10.74リットルとほぼ現代と同じになった。
sen.e: In the age of the Later Han dynasty, 1 "to" was reduced to 1.98 liter, but after that, the size of "to" continued to grow - for example, in the age of the Wei and West Jin dynasties, 1 "to" was set at 2.02 liters, and in the age of the Sui and Tang dynasties, 1 "to" was set at 5.94 liters, and in the age of the Ming dynasty, 1 "to" was set at 10.74 liters, almost the same size as today's.

In the age of the Later Han Dynasty, 1 to was reduced to 1.98 liters, but after that, the size continued to grow as 1 to was set at 2.02 liters in the age of the Wei and West Jin Dynasties, 5.94 liters in the age of the Sui and Tang Dynasties, and was set at 10.74 liters, which was almost the same size as present, in the age of the Ming Dynasty.

In the age of the Later Han Dynasty, 1 to was reduced to 1.98 liters, but after that, the size continued to grow as 1 to was set at 2.02 liters in the age of the Wei and West Jin Dynasties, 5.94 liters in the age of the Sui and Tang Dynasties, and was set at 10.74 liters, which was almost the same size as present, in the age of the Ming Dynasty.

sen.j: 約1斗の容積を持つ直方体形のブリキ缶は、日本ではかつて「一斗缶」と呼ばれていた。
sen.e: In Japan, the cuboid tin can of about 1 "to" volume was once called "1-to-can."
In Japan, the cuboid tin can of about 1 to volume was once called 'Ittokan' (can of 1 to).
In Japan, the cuboid tin can of about 1 to volume was once called 'Ittokan' (can of 1 to).

sen.j: 第二次世界大戦後は「五ガロン缶」という名称が広まったが、後に「18リットル缶」が正式名称とされた。
sen.e: After World War Ⅱ, the name "five-gallon-can" became popular, and later, it was formally renamed into "18-liter-can."
After World War II, it was widely called as 'go-gallon kan' (can of 5 gallons), and later, it was formally renamed into 'Juhachi-liter kan' (can of 18 liters).
After World War II, it was widely called as 'go-gallon kan' (can of 5 gallons), and later, it was formally renamed into 'Juhachi-liter kan' (can of 18 liters).

sen.j: 灯油などを入れるプラスチック製の容器（通称：ポリタンク）は一斗缶の代替として作られたものであり、その容積は1斗（18リットル）か、それより少し多い20リットルである。
sen.e: The plastic tank for storing kerosene and other liquid, commonly called "poli-tank" (standing for 'polystyrene tank'), was made as a replacement for 1-to-can, and the volume of poli-tank is 1 "to" (18 liters), or a bit larger, 20 liters.

The plastic tank for storing kerosene and other liquid (commonly called poli-tank [polystyrene tank]) was made as a replacement for Ittokan, of which volume is 1 to (18 liters) or a bit larger, 20 liters.

The plastic tank for storing kerosene and other liquid (commonly called poli-tank [polystyrene tank]) was made as a replacement for Ittokan, of which volume is 1 to (18 liters) or a bit larger, 20 liters.
